units.title: Neural Induction
units.text: We use the dual-SMAD inhibitors dorsomorphin (4 μM) and SB-431542 (10 μM) in neurobasal media with the vitamin A-containing B27 supplement for neural induction (Figs. 1 and 2a–c).
units.rationale: This step details the specific reagents and concentrations used to induce neural differentiation from pluripotent stem cells.

units.title: Neural Rosette Formation
units.text: We treat the cultures of neuroepithelial cells with fibroblast growth factor 2 (FGF2, 10 ng/mL) and epidermal growth factor (EGF, 10 ng/mL)59,60.
units.rationale: This step specifies the growth factors required to promote neural rosette formation from neuroepithelial cells.

units.title: Manual SNR Isolation
units.text: We manually isolate SNRs that are ~200–300 μm in diameter for organoid generation (Fig. 2f).
units.rationale: This step describes the critical manual procedure for selecting viable single neural rosettes for organoid development.

units.title: SNR Propagation in Suspension
units.text: We transfer isolated SNRs to a low-adhesion 96-well plate (one SNR per well) and maintain them on an orbital shaker in the N2/B27(with vitamin A) media with FGF2 and EGF for 2 weeks (Figs. 1 and 3).
units.rationale: This step outlines the culture conditions required for SNRs to develop into organoids in suspension.

units.title: MG Embedding of Organoids
units.text: We adopted the approach developed by Lancaster and Knoblich27 and embedded SNR-derived organoids into Matrigel (MG) droplets (Fig. 5a).
units.rationale: This step describes the key procedure of embedding organoids in Matrigel to enable further tissue growth.

units.title: Organoid Maturation with Trophic Factors
units.text: Between 3 and 4 months post-embedding, we treat organoids with brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), neurotrophin-3 (NT3) and glial-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) (Fig. 1) to promote neuronal survival, maturation and synapse development62,63.
units.rationale: This step specifies the timing and factors used to mature neurons and synapses in long-term organoid cultures.

units.title: SNR-Derived Organoid Dissociation for scRNA-seq (1-month-old)
units.text: Transfer 1-month-old organoids (before MG embedding) to a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube using a P200 pipette tip cut to avoid damaging the organoids. Let orga-noids settle to the bottom, aspirate the medium and rinse once with sterile PBS. Carefully remove the PBS without collecting organoids.
units.rationale: This step provides the precise initial procedure for dissociating 1-month-old organoids prior to single-cell RNA sequencing.

units.title: Organoid Dissociation for scRNA-seq (5-month-old)
units.text: Transfer an organoid to a 6 cm dish with ice-cold oxygenated cutting ACSF using a P1000 pipette tip cut to avoid damaging the organoid.
units.rationale: This step initiates the specialized dissociation protocol for mature organoids prior to scRNA-seq, requiring cryo-preservation and slicing.

units.title: Immunohistochemistry Fixation
units.text: Discard the supernatant, add 250 μL of 4% PFA and incubate overnight at 4 °C.
units.rationale: This step defines the fixation protocol essential for preserving organoid structure prior to immunostaining.

units.title: Slice Patch-Clamp Electrophysiology
units.text: Cut 350-µm-thick slices using the vibratome set to 100 Hz frequency, 1.2 mm amplitude and a slow (3–6 mm/min) forward movement velocity (Fig. 9b).
units.rationale: This step specifies the precise vibratome settings required to generate viable brain organoid slices for electrophysiological recording.
